bboxes.raw_text:
Valley Beautiful Citizens
Council is endorsing the "Jobs
for Youth campaign being CO..
spoons ored by the Phoenix Jay
Gees and Arizona State Employ
ment Service.


1t praised local media for the
latter's role in publicizing &C
tivities designed to stimulate
summertime employment for
thousands of Valley high school
and college students.


VBCC chairman Lewis ]. Rus
kin said he has urged all Council
members and volunteers to enlist
in the Jaycees-ASES campaign.


"Even in our best kept sections

there are fences that need paint
ing, alleys that need cleaning.
hedges that need trimming--all
Jobs which can be performed by
these responsible young people,"
Ruskin noted.


Such employment, he said, will
mean important income for stu
dents, as we'll as a noticeable
impr ovement in the Valley S ap-
pearance. Ruskin also pointed out
that industry, warehouses, mo-
tells and other large land-users
could undertake summertime
"spruce up projects employing
students.

Valley Beautiful Council Says
Youth Can Help

Eleven million adults In the
United States are illiterate, re-
ports the National Education As
siciation (NEA).


In addition to those who can
not read or write. says the NEA,
more than % million l8 years
old and over have never gone past
the seventh grade, and 81 per
cent of the population has not
completed high school.

II MILLION ADULTS
ILLITERkTE IN USA

Lee A. Limbs. Jr., of 1917
E. Adams, established two firsts
when he became deputy US.
marshall.


Limbs is the first Negro ever
to serve as a deputy marshal
in Arizona. At "a, he also is the
youngest of 10 deputies serving
in Arizona.


Limbs attended Mesa High
School, Phoenix College and the
University of Arizona. He for
merly was a Maricopa County
deputy sheriff.

Limbs Is First
US. Deputy Marshal
In Arizona

NEW YORK - June IL, the
anniversary of the ambush slay-
ing of Medgar Evers, Mississ-
ippi field secretary of the Ma
tional Association for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People,
will be observed in more than
200 communities with special
memorial services.

Roy Wilkins, NAACP executive
secretary, urged all Americans
to support the Evers Memorial
membership drive and the Evers
Memorial Fund.


He said small but significant
gains had been made in Mississ-
ippi since the Staying, but
Negroes are still faced with
strong police measures.

Anniversary Programs Set For


Slain Medgur Evers

LAS VEGAS. New. The Ne
vada Athletic Commission re-
ports former world heavyweight
champion Joe Louis is one of
eight men who have asked to
referee welterweight title
match june IL.


Emile Griffith will be defend
ing his crown in l5-round
match with Luis Rodriguez.

David Banks, a l5-year-old
freshman at Phoenix South Noun
tain High School. won the Ari-
iona championship of the Opti-
mists International oratorical
contest.


Five contestants we're judged
on five-minute speeches "Op-
timism Formula for Freedom"
at the Ramada Inn.


Banks received a wrist watch
and a gold-plated trophy and
will represent Arizona in a ma
tional oratory contest June 10
in Denver.


David, son of MIR. and Mrs.
Fred Banks of 1885 E. Wier,
Phoenix, earlier defeated so
competitors in two preliminary
contests held at Phoenix. He was
coached by Lucille Hicks, speech
teacher at South Mountain High
School.

of the 1864 graduating class
of Palmdae School, 3l4o E. Wer.


Recipients include Tommie Boone CT Joan Colbert and Ber
nice Cochran Principals Gloria Williams Alpha; Ollie
Links Christopher Brown Arizona ibune Frank Evans Urban
League; Dorothy Richardson Careers True
Goodoe, Student Counc Velma Hamilton Newsette and 9TH
grade Evans Scouts Juan Pop Warner
Gauff and Dorothy Richardson 9TH grade.

The Percy L. Julian Award of 1864 presented Roy Me-
foyer by Miss cquene Smith, former Julian Award winner.
The Julian School grada
ton exercises held We'd. May 27.
